description.narrative: Since 2018, Oxfam has renewed its commitment to safeguarding, including strengthening policies, developing procedures, and focusingon ensuring that programs and staff do not cause harm to the individuals and communities where programmes are implemented.This has been achieved through training staff to build expertise across multiple roles in Safe Programming, identifying potentially unsafe situations, and making mitigation plans that reduce risk for the people Oxfam serves. Oxfam’s safe programming approach recognizes thepotential for causing harm and requires us to take proactive measures to prevent or mitigate risks in our programs. Oxfam Somalia is implementing humanitarian and development programs across the country in collaboration with local partners with operations mainlyin remote and hard to reach areas. The Humanitarian Programme focuses on 3 main sectors i.e. WASH, EFSVL and Protection. Oxfam Somalia has made efforts towards ensuring the strengthening of safe programming in its programmes through training of staff, appointing separate safeguarding and safegrograming focal points, capacity building of partners and also ensuring that each Programme has risk assessments and mitigation plans in place. Despite these efforts more needs to be doneto ensure that the safe programming is strengthened in our programmes. Recent monitoring visits in local partners program areas have identified the following gaps when it comes to safe programming: There is generally varying understanding of theconcept of safe programming amongst partners which results in different approaches being adopted to ensure programmes are safe. There is a room for improvement in operationalizing uniform approach. There is a general absence of clear systems and processes that facilitate the implementation of the safe programming approach. There is a need to improve knowledge and skills related to implementing safe programming approach and define clear roles and responsibilities in adopting safe programming in different levels of the organization. With these observations there, Oxfam seeks to ensure the strengthening of understanding of safe programming, ensuring a uniform approach with its partners and also making sure systems are put in place for the operationalizationof safe programming. Specific objective 1: Oxfam and partner staff know and understand the safe programming approach and are able to put it into a practice. Specific objective 2: Systems and process which facilitate a safe programming approach are in place and working. Specific objective 3: Safe programming risks are systematically identified and mitigated for all programmes and projects.

participating-org.narrative: In 2004 Oxfam Novib set up a Liaison Office in Nairobi, Kenya in order to support the Strengthening Somali Civil Society Program, at the request of the EU. This request was based on Oxfam Novib's work in Somalia to date, but intended to be more widely directed atthe entire civil society sector and the specific context in which it is operating in a post-conflict country. The program started with consulting local organisations in Somalia and Somaliland to get a complete picture of the sectors and regions where they are active, the challenges they face and the relationship between civil society, local political structures and the private sector. A program was then developed to strengthen the institutional development of Oxfam Novib's partners and those of other Oxfams, as well as a range of new NGOs. In the first year local consultants were trained in Somalia. They were then seconded to civil society organisations to build their capacity in financial and organisational management. Furthermore, workshops were organised on specific themes suchas human rights and the role of civil society in the Somali context. The Liaison Office is now going to support the expansion of the program, focussing on strengthening both organisation and project management, while facilitating more training in the fields of civic education, governance, human rights and women's rights, HIV and AIDS and child protection. Over the years, the Somalia Country Office has expanded its intervention on short term humanitarian response as well as development development interventions. In 2015/2016, a decision was reached to move the Country Programme operation, which was largely in Nairobi, from Nairobi to Hargeisa. The country office has a small office in Nairobi , Kenya and large operations office in Hargeisa, Somaliland.
